data.description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Today, millions of people come here each year to camp, hike, and enjoy the majesty of the park.

emailAddresses.description: Contact Yellowstone's park rangers for general park questions, lost and found, or for special use permits.

entranceFees.description: Good for entry into Yellowstone National Park for seven days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (non-commercial vehicle)

entranceFees.description: Good for entry into Yellowstone National Park for seven days from the date of purchase. Snowmobile entry limited to guided tours or permit holders.
entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (motorcycle or snowmobile)

entranceFees.description: Good for entry into Yellowstone National Park for seven days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Yellowstone (individual on foot, bicycle, etc.)

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance into Yellowstone National Park for one year (valid through the month of purchase). On a snowmobile, this pass admits the signer(s). When traveling by snowcoach or shuttle, this pass admits a signer and up to three additional persons (16 and older) for a total of four people.
entrancePasses.title: Yellowstone National Park Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.

operatingHours.description: Yellowstone is open daily, year-round, although activities and services are limited at night and certain times of year. The park has five entrance stations, but not all entrance stations are open year-round. Make sure to carefully read about access at each station at different times of year. And remember, all dates are weather-dependent.Please note that camping is possible only in designated campgrounds.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

operatingHours.description: Adjacent to the town of West Yellowstone, Montana, the West Entrance is usually open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow (snowmobiles and snowcoaches) vehicles from December 15 to March 15.
operatingHours.name: West Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway community of Gardiner, Montana, the North Entrance is the only park entrance open to wheeled vehicles all year. November through April, the North Entrance provides the only access to Cooke City, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. The road from Mammoth to Norris opens to wheeled vehicles the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow vehicles, conditions permitting, from December 15 to early March.
operatingHours.name: North Entrance

operatingHours.description: Depending on the weather and conditions, this entrance usually opens to wheeled vehicles the first Friday in May and to tracked-oversnow vehicles December 22 through March 15.
operatingHours.name: East Entrance

operatingHours.description: Open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the second Friday in May through early November and to tracked-oversnow vehicles from December 15 to March 15. Limited services are available near the South Entrance.
operatingHours.name: South Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway communities of Silver Gate and Cooke City, Montana, this entrance is open year around for wheeled vehicle access to Cooke City through Gardiner, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. Opening dates for roads east of Cooke City vary from year to year, depending on the weather. The Beartooth Highway is open from late May/early June (weather dependent) to mid October.
operatingHours.name: Northeast Entrance

images.title: Grand Prismatic Spring
images.altText: Brilliant blues and greens of a hot spring ringed by oranges, yellows, reds, and browns.
images.caption: The bright colors found in Grand Prismatic Spring come from thermophiles—microorganisms that thrive in hot temperatures

images.title: Aurum Geyser
images.altText: A crowd of people standing along a wooden boardwalk watches a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Aurum Geyser erupting

images.title: Black Pool
images.altText: A visitor stands on a boardwalk near a hot spring and a lake.
images.caption: Black Pool at the West Thumb Geyser Basin

images.title: Beehive Geyser
images.altText: People on a wooden boardwalk watch a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Visitors to the Upper Geyser Basin watch Beehive Geyser erupt.

images.title: Wolf howling
images.altText: A wolf howls while standing on a snowy field.
images.caption: Alpha male of the Canyon wolf pack

images.title: Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum
images.altText: Visitors walk into a rustic, log and stone building.
images.caption: The stone-and-log architecture of Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum became a prototype for park buildings all around the country

images.title: Great Fountain Geyser
images.altText: A geyser erupting in the middle of a large pool.
images.caption: Great Fountain Geyser erupts against a blue summer sky

images.title: Old Faithful Geyser in winter
images.altText: A crowd in front of an erupting geyser during a snowy winter day.
images.caption: Winter is a magical time to watch Old Faithful Geyser erupt

images.title: Palette Spring
images.altText: Visitors walk in front of a brightly colored, terraced landscape.
images.caption: The vibrant colors of Palette Springs are formed by thermophiles—heat-loving organisms

images.title: Bighorn sheep
images.altText: Two bighorn sheep laying on the ground.
images.caption: Two bighorn rams rest and chew their cud

images.title: Lower Falls from Artist Point
images.altText: A river plunges into a steep, barren canyon.
images.caption: Lower Falls from Artist Point

images.title: Bison herd in a thermal area
images.altText: A herd of bison grazing through a barren and steaming thermal area.
images.caption: Bison near Mud Volcano

images.title: Grizzly bear
images.altText: A grizzly bear standing on a fallen tree.
images.caption: Grizzly bear in the woods

images.title: Yellowstone River
images.altText: A greenish river meanders through a hilly river valley.
images.caption: The Yellowstone River near Tower Fall

data.weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70°F (25°C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below 0°F (-18°C), especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.
data.name: Yellowstone

data.description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven days.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial car, pickup truck, RV, or van with 15 or fewer passenger seats

entranceFees.description: The fee is valid for seven days. Cost is per motorcycle (not per person).
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee is valid for seven days. People 15 years and younger are free. Cost is per person.
entranceFees.title: Foot, bicycle, horse, or non-commercial bus or van with more than 15 passenger seats

entranceFees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Tour (sedan up to six seats)
Commercial Tour (van, 7-15 seats, regardless of occupancy)
Commercial Tour (mini bus, 16-25 seats, regardless of occupancy)
Commercial Tour (motor coach, 26 or more seats, regardless of occupancy)

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass providing free entrance to Yosemite for 12 months from the date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Yosemite Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for national parks and other federal fee areas, valid for 12 months from date of purchase. This replaces the National Parks Pass and Golden Eagle Pass.
entrancePasses.title: America the Beautiful—National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime or annual admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents who are age 62 or older. An annual version of this pass, valid for 12 months, costs $20.
entrancePasses.title: Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description: Lifetime admission and discount pass for US citizens or permanent residents with permanent disabilities.
entrancePasses.title: Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance and standard amenity fees for all active US military personnel and their dependents, valid for 12 months from date of issuance. (For active duty military personnel and dependents with proper identification (CAC Card or DD Form 1173).)
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass for US Military

entrancePasses.description: Annual pass covering entrance fees for 4th grade students for 2018–2019 school year.
entrancePasses.title: Annual 4th Grade Pass

data.directionsInfo: You can drive to Yosemite year-round and enter via Highways 41, 140, and 120 from the west. Tioga Pass Entrance (via Highway 120 from the east) is closed from approximately November through late May or June. Hetch Hetchy is open all year but may close intermittently due to snow. Please note that GPS units do not always provide accurate directions to or within Yosemite.

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Yosemite National Park

operatingHours.description: Hetch Hetchy area is only open during the day (except for permitted backpackers). All day visitors must exit Hetch Hetchy by the closure time.
operatingHours.name: Hetch Hetchy

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.altText: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring

images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.altText: Glaciated valley with vertical cliffs.
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.title: Glen Aulin
images.altText: Mountains reflecting in water
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.altText: Mountains surrounding a lake.
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.

images.title: Half Dome
images.altText: Granite dome with trace amounts of snow.
images.caption: Half Dome is one of the most recognizable granitic formations in the world.

images.title: El Capitan
images.altText: El Capitan and reflection in Merced River with some low clouds
images.caption: El Capitan rises over 3,000 feet above the floor of Yosemite Valley.

data.weatherInfo: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)
data.name: Yosemite

data.description: Follow the paths where native people and pioneers walked. Gaze up at massive sandstone cliffs of cream, pink, and red that soar into a brilliant blue sky. Experience wilderness in a narrow slot canyon. Zion’s unique array of plants and animals will enchant you as you absorb the rich history of the past and enjoy the excitement of present day adventures.

emailAddresses.description: If you cannot find what you need on our website, please write to ask for more information.

entranceFees.description: Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants to Zion National Park, including both the Zion Canyon and Kolob Canyon areas.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle: Valid for 7 days.

entranceFees.description: Admits one non-commercial motorcycle to Zion National Park, including both the Zion Canyon and Kolob Canyon areas.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle: Valid for 7 days.

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car to Zion National Park, including both the Zion Canyon and Kolob Canyon areas. Typically used for bicyclists, hikers and pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Per Person: Valid for 7 days.

entranceFees.description: Organized groups such as Scouts, Clubs, Youth Groups, Churches, Reunions, etc. that do not qualify for an Academic Fee Waiver are charged as follows: $35.00 Non-commercial vehicles with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less.$20.00 per person Non-commercial vehicles with a capacity of 16 or greater. Fees will not exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate.
entranceFees.title: Non-Commercial Organized Groups: Valid for 7 days.

entrancePasses.description: Admission to all Federal fee areas for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Interagency Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Admission to Zion National Park for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Zion Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Admission to all federal fee areas for one year from date of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description: Admission to all federal fee areas for life, U.S. citizens 62 years or older.
entrancePasses.title: Lifetime Senior Pass

entrancePasses.description: Admission to all federal fee areas for life, permanently disabled U.S. citizens
entrancePasses.title: Lifetime Access Pass

entrancePasses.description: Since Veterans Day 2020, Gold Star Families and US military veterans are eligible to receive free access to more than 2,000 federal recreation areas, including national parks, wildlife refuges, and forests. The free access program is a way to thank America’s veterans, Gold Star Families, and current military and their dependents for their support of our country.Learn more: https://www.nps.gov/planyourvisit/veterans-and-gold-star-families-free-access.htm
entrancePasses.title: Free Access for Veterans and Gold Star Families

entrancePasses.description: Admission to all federal fee areas for one year from issue date. Volunteers with over 250 hours of service are eligible.
entrancePasses.title: Volunteer Pass

data.directionsInfo: Zion National Park is located on State Route 9 in Springdale, Utah. You may drive yourself on all open park roads except the Zion Canyon Scenic Drive. During most of the year, the Scenic Drive is accessed by shuttle bus only. Shuttles are free and can be found at the Zion Canyon Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description: Zion National Park is open every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Zion National Park

images.title: Temples and Towers of the Virgin
images.altText: A towering sandstone rock formation.
images.caption: The Temples and Towers can be seen from the back patio of the Human History Museum.

images.title: Zion Canyon Visitor Center
images.altText: Zion Canyon Visitor Center with a sandstone peak in the background
images.caption: The Zion Canyon Visitor Center sits near the sandstone peak known as the Watchman

images.title: Mountain of the Sun
images.altText: A white and pink sandstone peak, lit up in the sunlight.
images.caption: The Mountain of the Sun in Zion Canyon.

images.title: The Zion Narrows
images.altText: A narrow canyon with a gentle river flowing in the bottom
images.caption: The Zion Narrows is a challenging wilderness experience.

images.title: Kolob Arch
images.altText: A large red sandstone arch high up on a cliff.
images.caption: Deep in Zion's Wilderness sits Kolob Arch, one of the largest free-standing arches in the world.

data.weatherInfo: Zion is known for a wide range of weather conditions. Temperatures vary with changes in elevation and day/night temperatures may differ by over 30°F. In summer, temperatures in Zion National Park often exceed 100°F/38°C. Zion experiences monsoons from mid-July into September that result in an increased risk of flash floods. Always be aware of the threat of storms and lightning and be prepared for a wide range of weather conditions. Winters are generally mild.
data.name: Zion
